record.attribute:
The Trichomonas vaginalis genome project was undertaken at The Institute for Genomic Research (TIGR) directed by Jane Carlton in collaboration with Patricia Johnson and the Trichomonas research community. Funding for the project was provided initially by a UO1 grant from NIAID/NIH and subsequently with funds from NIAID's Microbial Sequencing Centers. The Burroughs Wellcome Fund and The Ellison Medical Foundation also provided funds for several community meetings. The project took 3 years 6 months to complete and cost an estimated $3.7 million. The paper describing the T. vaginalis genome was published as the front cover article in Science in January 2007.

The T. vaginalis sequencing effort was complemented by EST data from the Chang Gung T. vaginalis Systems Biology Project, directed by Petrus Tang and supported by grants from Chang Gung Memorial Hospital and Taiwan Biotech Company Limited. Details of the T. vaginalis ESTs generated by Chang Gung University can be obtained from the website http://TvXpress.cgu.edu.tw.

Genome size ~160 MB
Size of assembly (bp) 176,441,227
Total no. reads sequenced 1,403,509
Average read length (bp) 785
No. scaffolds 17,290
N50 scaffold size1 (bp) 68,338
Coverage ~7.2x
%G+C 32.7
Genes 
Protein-coding 
  No. predicted 59,672
  Mean length (bp) 928.6
  %G+C 35.5
  Density2 (bp) 2,956
  No. evidence-supported3 ~26,000
  No. containing introns 65
RNA 
  tRNA 468
  5.8S/18S/28S rDNA units ~250
Other 
  Repeat genes4 38,201
Intergenic regions 
  Mean length (bp) 1,165.40
  %G+C 28.8

1the minimum scaffold length, such that more than half of the genome is contained in scaffolds of at least that length
2on average, there is one gene per this many base pairs in the genome
3includes genes with either similarity to a known protein (E-value < 1 x 10-10, >25% length of protein), or similarity to an EST (>95% identity over >90% length of the gene)
4includes virus-like, transposon-like, retrotransposon-like, and unclassified repeats, all with high copy number and low polymorphism



  • The EuPathDB Data Summary provides an overview of the content in Eu PathDB across sites, all organisms and data types covered.
  • The EuPathDB Gene Metrics Table summarizes the number of genes for the o rganisms currently available in EuPathDB, by various datatypes.

There are several kinds of downloads available in a EuPathDB site:
  • Download files that we create at release time. The link to access these files is under the menu item "Downloads":"Data Files". These include fasta files for all available sequences, gff files with complete gene information, and other formats.
  • Download files with results generated by running searches. From a result page (after running a search) a user can access the "Download Results" link, to a new page where a few different download formats are offered. The file for download includes all IDs in the result. The user selects a format and, in some formats, the user may request additional information about each ID in the result: single valued attributes (e.g., exon count for a geneID) and multi-valued tables (e.g., set of EC numbers for a geneID).
  • Download files that have been uploaded by the community in our websites, available under "Downloads" or "Community".
  • Download EuPathDB publications, under the menu item "Downloads".

Our thanks to previous advisors:
  • Steven Sullivan
  • Jane Carlton.

EuPathDB is pleased to announce the members of the scientific working group (SWG). The SWG provides EuPathDB with scientific oversight and guidance. Members of the SWG also review the driving biological projects initiative.

EuPathDB wishes to acknowledge all the community members who have contributed data (often pre-publication), entered user comments or sent us their suggestions.

Scanning electron micrograph showing T. vaginalis parasites. One amoeboid parasite is shown adhering to vaginal epithelial cells (pink) collected from vaginal swabs; a second non-adhered parasite is pear-shaped. Antonio Pereira-Neves and Marlene Benchimol, Santa Ursula University, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

TrichDB is a member of pathogen-databases that are housed under the NIAID-funded EuPathDB Bioinformatics Resource Center (BRC) umbrella. The EuPathDB team is mainly distributed between the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and the University of Georgia in Athens, Georgia.

The data at this site is provided freely for public use, through the contributions of many researchers including those involved in generating the genome sequences. The data is not guaranteed to be accurate as it often reflects the results of ongoing research. When using data obtained from TrichDB, it is important to cite the original publications and contributors of that data and TrichDB. Please see Citing TrichDB below.

When citing TrichDB itself, please use:

GiardiaDB and TrichDB: integrated genomic resources for the eukaryotic protist pathogens Giardia lamblia and Trichomonas vaginalis. 2009 Jan;37(Database issue):D526-30. Aurrecoechea C, et al.

Much of the data in TrichDB is provided by independent researchers. Please cite them if you use their data. For a list of the data integrated into TrichDB and the related publications please see Data Sources.
